<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92714111">
  <div id="comment_inner_92714111" class="comment cpic recommended not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92714111">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92714111'); return false">One of the many powerful effects of Holliday's dust. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92714111" class="cbody">
      <p>While the dust remains in effect, Skip receives a +3 bonus to all swings, +4 against fastballs, automatically succeeds in all diving to first-related saving throws, and has vorpal added.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on

<a name="92739496"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92739496">
  <div id="comment_inner_92739496" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/MdRedbirdFreak"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/5545/Willie_desktop_Q-2_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92739496">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92739496'); return false">Yes, and that tradition</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92739496" class="cbody">
      <p>isn’t just strategic, it’s cultural.  Your #3 hitter is usually one of your franchise’s core players and that spot in the lineup is given to him not only for his production but also as a sign of respect and recognition for his centrality to the team.  Clearly in that context Holliday has to be your #3 now, and probably for most if not all the rest of his contract.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/MdRedbirdFreak">MdRedbirdFreak</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92739496">

<a name="92715388"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92715388">
  <div id="comment_inner_92715388" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/lightbulb"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/164538/jonstupidhead_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92715388">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92715388'); return false">Wouldn't The Book say to put someone like Beltran in the leadoff spot?</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92715388" class="cbody">
      <p>High OBP, good power.</p>
<p>From <a href="http://www.beyondtheboxscore.com/2009/3/17/795946/optimizing-your-lineup-by" target="new">BtB </a>on lineup construction in The Book:</p>
<p>Lead-Off</p>
<p>The old-school book says to put a speedy guy up top.  Power isn’t important, and OBP is nice, but comes second to speed.</p>
<blockquote>The Book says OBP is king.  The lead-off hitter comes to bat only 36% of the time with a runner on base, versus 44% of the time for the next lowest spot in the lineup, so why waste homeruns?  The lead-off hitter also comes to the plate the most times per game, so why give away outs?  As for speed, stealing bases is most valuable in front of singles hitters, and since the top of the order is going to be full of power hitters, they’re not as important.  The lead-off hitter is one of the best three hitters on the team, the guy without homerun power.  Speed is nice, as this batter will have plenty of chances to run the bases with good hitters behind him.</blockquote>
<p>I know there’s a 0% chance that would happen in the real-world lineup, but if we’re going strictly by The Book, it could be more like:<br>
Beltran<br>
Holliday<br>
Yadi<br>
Berkman<br>
Freese<br>
Yadi<br>
Greene<br>
Pitcher<br>
Jay</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p><a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115734/quotes" target="new">Dignan</a>: On the run from Johnny Law... ain't no trip to Cleveland.</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/lightbulb">lightbulb</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92715388">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 10:33 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92714606'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92715388); return false" id="comment_reply_92715388">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92715388" class="tools">
          <a href="#" class="actions_link" onclick="SBN.Comments.loadTools(92715388); return false">actions</a>
        </span>
        <span id="comment_rating_92715388">&nbsp; 
          
            1  recs
          
        </span>
      </span>
    </p>
  </div>

<a name="92715762"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92715762">
  <div id="comment_inner_92715762" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92715762">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92715762'); return false">I would agree with that. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92715762" class="cbody">
      <p>I like Beltran ahead of those guys, rather than behind them.</p>
<p>I love the notion of Greene in the seven hole, right ahead of the pitcher. He gets on base, he should have the Greene Light (I’m thinking this should be a thing at the stadium whenever he steals a base), to always try and take the extra base without fear of ruining a big inning.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on

      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92739185'); return false">Sorry, I guess MM didn't mention Beltran by name, Hummel did</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92739185" class="cbody">
      <blockquote>Matheny said, "If you have some speed, show it. That’s going to be the philosophy. If guys have speed in their repertoire, they certainly need to display it and improve on it and take advantage of some of the special instructors we have in here.<br>
<br>
“And we’re going to have some early and some late (basestealing) sessions as well.”</blockquote>
<p>and</p>
<blockquote>“I do believe there are some guys in here who can steal some bases,” said Matheny. "Now do you take a whole team and all of a sudden try to turn them into basestealers? No, you play the hand that you’re dealt. Why force that issue?<br>
<br>
“But we’ve got some guys who it’s going to be fun to watch use their instincts this spring.”</blockquote>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92770693">
  <div id="comment_inner_92770693" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/MdRedbirdFreak"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/5545/Willie_desktop_Q-2_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>

<a name="92728240"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92728240">
  <div id="comment_inner_92728240" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/zeruko"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/537593/311932_906971694419_12802943_40701435_1642279249_n_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92728240">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92728240'); return false">i get the reasoning</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92728240" class="cbody">
      <p>but in practice, there aren’t a lot of high-OBP, low-SLG guys out there. no pop guys tend to get less respect from opposing pitchers, so the only guys that fit this mold are the super-high contact guys, like ichiro and figgins (pre-mariners). so, you’re most likely going to end up with a speedy, ~.330 OBP guy, or a beltran type who might have some lead-off HRs ‘wasted’. this seems to be approach the royals took with alex gordon last year.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/zeruko">zeruko</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92728240">

<a name="92715228"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92715228">
  <div id="comment_inner_92715228" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/581993/1989_bgh_Cropped_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92715228">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92715228'); return false">Matheny's organization of camp.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92715228" class="cbody">
      <p>The reports from Langosch that Matheny is mixing veterans and minor leaguers in Spring Training groups and making pitchers throw to every catcher so they’re comfortable with every catcher struck me as being so common-sensical that I couldn’t figure out why La Russa didn’t organize camp this way. I think this is a very positive development for the team. What are your thoughts?</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"I'm gonna throw the nastiest curveball I have ever thrown...if he hits it, I'll tip my cap, but if not we're going to the Series."</p>

<p>--Adam Wainwright on the final pitch of the 2006 NLCS</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh">bgh</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92715228">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 10:30 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92715228); return false" id="comment_reply_92715228">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92715228" class="tools">

<a name="92715487"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92715487">
  <div id="comment_inner_92715487" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92715487">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92715487'); return false">It seems to make all the sense in the world to me as well. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92715487" class="cbody">
      <p>It also seems to be a very inclusive, new age-y kind of way of running things that would likely seem antithetical to La Russa’s ideas of what young player decorum should be. Matheny wants youngsters to learn by being around the veterans; La Russa wanted youngsters to learn by observing the veterans. I think this way is better. But, time will tell.</p>
<p>I like the catcher thing as well, though I think long term it probably means a little less. It’s nice to know all the pitchers have at least a passing familiarity with any and all of the catchers, but I don’t know how much honest impact that will have down the road. Although I will say I think that could end up a much better learning experience for the catchers than the pitchers.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92715487">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 10:35 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92715228'); return false">up</a>

<a name="92716648"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92716648">
  <div id="comment_inner_92716648" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/581993/1989_bgh_Cropped_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92716648">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92716648'); return false">As I read the report, I believe it is a new way of doing things.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92716648" class="cbody">
      <p>From <a href="http://stlouis.cardinals.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120219&amp;content_id=26756506&amp;notebook_id=26756508&amp;vkey=notebook_stl&amp;c_id=stl">Langosch</a>:</p>
<blockquote>This idea of pairing the most experienced with the youngsters was proposed by Matheny and immediately embraced by the veterans. <br>
<br>
“Not every organization has guys that want to buy into that,” Matheny said. “I think they see the bigger picture that we have the opportunity to influence this organization for years to come. And if we put some of these kids out there on Field Z near Egypt, there’s not going to be much of a chance to see how these guys go about things on a daily basis.” </blockquote>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"I'm gonna throw the nastiest curveball I have ever thrown...if he hits it, I'll tip my cap, but if not we're going to the Series."</p>

<p>--Adam Wainwright on the final pitch of the 2006 NLCS</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh">bgh</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92716648">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 10:50 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92716191'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92716648); return false" id="comment_reply_92716648">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92716648" class="tools">
          <a href="#" class="actions_link" onclick="SBN.Comments.loadTools(92716648); return false">actions</a>

        <span id="comment_rating_92716648">&nbsp; 
          
        </span>

    </p>
  </div>

    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92757184" class="cbody">
      <p>mix the always posters with the mostly lurkers</p>
<p>“that’s not quite the right way to do that meme”<br>
“nice double entendre”<br>
“work on the punctuation”<br>
“don’t take that shit from fourstick, fight back”</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Just win</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Duke">The Duke</a> on

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92715951">
  <div id="comment_inner_92715951" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92715951">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92715951'); return false">I don't know. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92715951" class="cbody">
      <p>That’s a tough one. It was frustrating at times, to be sure, but there are also what I think are some very good, very legitimate reasons for sitting guys in getaway games from time to time. It did seem as if La Russa took it to the extreme when a sweep was on the line, though.</p>
<p>I think Matheny will probably be a little less inclined toward heavy lineup changes and the like, at least at first. I expect he may tinker down the road a bit more, but as he eases into a comfort level with the job he’ll probably play it straight.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div>

<a name="92718227"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92718227">
  <div id="comment_inner_92718227" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92718227">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92718227'); return false">A win in the hand, and all that. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92718227" class="cbody">
      <p>If you plan ahead to do that, you’re reducing your chances of winning two games ahead of time, increasing the chances of you going into the third game of the series needing it to win. Push as hard as possible the first two, and once you’ve got those two wins in hand there’s no risk at all of you losing the series.</p>
<p>That’s kind of the way I would look at it, anyway.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92718227">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 11:12 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92718045'); return false">up</a>

<a name="92719137"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92719137">
  <div id="comment_inner_92719137" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/mattybobo"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/457563/200px-HatB_-_Ozzie_Smith_s_misfortune_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92719137">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92719137'); return false">It was one of those things where I totally understood the logic behind it, and even thought it might be a good idea on paper</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92719137" class="cbody">
      <p>I just hated seeing it as a fan, because it usually made the game less fun for me. It brought up frustrating emotions because I would start to forecast bench players playing badly in my head, and would have reduced expectations of winning. Sometimes it is hard to balance logic and emotions as a fan, just as it must be difficult to balance the season-long goals of a team with the short-term goals of individuals games and series.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"I'll be deep in the cold, cold ground before I recognize Missoura!"</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/mattybobo">mattybobo</a> on

<a name="92719296"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92719296">
  <div id="comment_inner_92719296" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92719296">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92719296'); return false">True. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92719296" class="cbody">
      <p>From an emotional standpoint it’s probably more frustrating. But from a performance standpoint I could actually see it being a more effective way of handling these situations.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on

<a name="92720665"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92720665">
  <div id="comment_inner_92720665" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/MdRedbirdFreak"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/5545/Willie_desktop_Q-2_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92720665">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92720665'); return false">Well, with this particular team you've got a</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92720665" class="cbody">
      <p>good situation though, given that the three non-catchers most in need of days off (Berk, Beltran and Holliday) can each be replaced for one game by Craig.  So you rest Berk Friday nite, Beltran Saturday, and unless you really must win Sunday, Holliday on Sunday, in each case replacing them with an impact bat.</p>
<p>Problem solved.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/MdRedbirdFreak">MdRedbirdFreak</a> on

<a name="92719208"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92719208">
  <div id="comment_inner_92719208" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92719208">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92719208'); return false">Well, you're doing a little bit of apples and oranges there because TLR never had that combination of players.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92719208" class="cbody">
      <p>Given that Craig would be the primary backup for Holliday (LF), Beltran (RF), and probably Berkman (1B), you probably would stagger their off-days so that Craig could get more PT and you’d lose as little as possible in performance.</p>
<p>But to the broader point of staggering rest or giving multiple starters rest on one day, I don’t know why it’s necessarily preferable to stagger.  It’s certainly not intuitively obvious that it’s better, especially when one considers that the other team may be staggering or may be using the “group rest” method.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92719208">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 11:25 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<a name="92722247"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92722247">
  <div id="comment_inner_92722247" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92722247">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92722247'); return false">if the goal is to maximize wins (and not hours of rest)</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92722247" class="cbody">
      <p>I think the best time to sit your players would be when your team is significantly better or significantly worse than your opponent. Just like wins for fringe playoff teams are more valuable, runs in a closely-matched contest are more valuable.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox">brackenthebox</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92722247">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:00 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<a name="92723484"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723484">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723484" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723484">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723484'); return false">This is true</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723484" class="cbody">
      <p>but the underlying assumption is that there is a relationship between the timing and amount of rest and winning.  Presumably the players most in need of rest (and it is not just “rest,” it is recovery time) are older players that play a lot (i.e., the veteran starters) when the recovery/rest time between games (as in a day game following a night game – the “travel day” game) is at a minimum.</p>
<p>If we assume that performance goes down for old players when recovery time is shorter (not a huge leap in logic) then we would want to remove those players when we think their performance is likely to be at its lowest — i.e., the travel day game.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92723484">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:15 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92722247'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92723484); return false" id="comment_reply_92723484">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92723484" class="tools">
          <a href="#" class="actions_link" onclick="SBN.Comments.loadTools(92723484); return false">actions</a>
        </span>
        <span id="comment_rating_92723484">&nbsp; 
          
        </span>
      </span>
    </p>

<a name="92723779"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723779">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723779" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723779">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723779'); return false">Yea, I can buy a recover time argument</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723779" class="cbody">
      <p>But that has nothing to do with whether you won/lost/split the first two games.</p>
<p>Ultimately, this feels a lot like lineup construction where it’s fun to debate cause there are lots of options, but it probably makes virtually no difference. Getting one extra game out of your starters is probably more valuable than optimally distributing a fixed number of rest innings.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox">brackenthebox</a> on

<a name="92724018"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92724018">
  <div id="comment_inner_92724018" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92724018">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92724018'); return false">also to this point</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92724018" class="cbody">
      <p>another approach is to be much more aggressive about pulling starters after getting out to a big lead/deficit. Especially if you’re in a night game before a day game. Again, you’re never going to see it due to morale, but a blanket policy to pull an old regular whenever your win probability is above 90% or below 10% would be interesting.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox">brackenthebox</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92724018">

        </a>

<a name="92725378"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92725378">
  <div id="comment_inner_92725378" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92725378">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92725378'); return false">Yes, that would be one way.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92725378" class="cbody">
      <p>But I don’t think the “rest/recovery” gained is linear with innings played.  A player probably gets more “rest/recovery” by not playing, or preparing to play, that day, than he does just in cutting off 2 innings at the end of the game.  There is also probably something to be said for a “mental” recovery day as well and in a player knowing he’s going to have a day off and then taking it (without preparing to play).</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92725378">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:36 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92724018'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92725378); return false" id="comment_reply_92725378">reply</a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92725570">
  <div id="comment_inner_92725570" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92725570">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92725570'); return false">*</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92725570" class="cbody">
      <p> should say “than he does just in cutting off 2-3 innings at the end of games, over 2-3 games.”</p>
<p>The point is that you might get more bang for your buck if you give an entire game off, rather than parsing it out in partial time off.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on

<a name="92726099"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92726099">
  <div id="comment_inner_92726099" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92726099">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92726099'); return false">yea, I think this is the overall problem</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92726099" class="cbody">
      <p>We don’t know much about how rest distribution affects player injury risk and/or recuperation. Presumably the players know a little about the latter (though not the former), but there’s still a lot of uncertainty. In contrast, we do know a lot (or can guess with high confidence) about how run distribution impacts winning. So in the brave new world of robot managers that is obviously right around the corner, run distribution should be weighted more heavily.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox">brackenthebox</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92726099">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:44 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92725570'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92726099); return false" id="comment_reply_92726099">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92726099" class="tools">
          <a href="#" class="actions_link" onclick="SBN.Comments.loadTools(92726099); return false">actions</a>
        </span>
        <span id="comment_rating_92726099">&nbsp; 
          
        </span>
      </span>
    </p>

<a name="92724543"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92724543">
  <div id="comment_inner_92724543" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Cardinals645"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/235473/Cards80s_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92724543">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92724543'); return false">I was thinking about that too.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92724543" class="cbody">
      <p>It shouldn’t impact the Expected Wins because the amount of RS-RA should be about the same. I do think which games you choose would be impacted by how much risk you want to take. For example, you could raise your win-floor by making sure your best players go against the weakest teams, and rest against the very strongest. Trying to win as many games as possible, you might instead rest guys against the weakest teams only. This, if I’m thinking about this correctly, would give you a shot at winning in each game, but also a shot at losing, so if you could get very different outcomes if you were very lucky or very unlucky.</p>
<p>But I think the differences here are probably very small. Also, I’m short on rest myself, so this might not be that well thought out.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Chief Economist of Tyler Greene Fanclub </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Cardinals645">Cardinals645</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92724543">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:27 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92722247'); return false">up</a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723038">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723038" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/581993/1989_bgh_Cropped_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723038">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723038'); return false">This is a strategic philosophy of La Russa's that I appreciated. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723038" class="cbody">
      <p>Nothing is more frustrating as a fan than being at a game in person and having him sit three starters but I appreciate that he wants to keep his players fresh throughout the season. If Craig returns at full health, resting the outfielders will be much, much easier. The Cardinals won’t lose that much. I also think the infield will be pretty easy to rest as well with Craig able to play first and the duo of Greene and Descalso able to play all second, short, and third.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"I'm gonna throw the nastiest curveball I have ever thrown...if he hits it, I'll tip my cap, but if not we're going to the Series."</p>

<p>--Adam Wainwright on the final pitch of the 2006 NLCS</p></div>

<a name="92716340"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92716340">
  <div id="comment_inner_92716340" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92716340">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92716340'); return false">I like it. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92716340" class="cbody">
      <p>A bit more melodic this time around, which I’m definitely in favour of. The first one had some great moments, but there was also a very large percentage of the time when what was good about them simply disappeared into obnoxious maximalism. Reign of Terror seems to have a little less of that.</p>
<p>I’m particularly fond of End of the Line, Leader of the Pack, and You Lost Me.</p>
<p>Honestly, though, I’ve only spun it once all the way through, so this is a very preliminary opinion.</p>
<p>What do you think?</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on

<a name="92716952"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92716952">
  <div id="comment_inner_92716952" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92716952">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92716952'); return false">Tip for reading critical reviews: </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92716952" class="cbody">
      <p>whenever the words, “__________’s second record,” appear, immediately add 30% positivity to any and all things you read after that. There’s a standard downgrade all reviewers apply to sophomore efforts that has to be factored in.</p>
<p>If the band in question came out of nowhere to shock everyone with their debut, you may have to adjust as much as 50% to account for the sophomore record effect.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92716952">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 10:54 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92716712'); return false">up</a>

    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92729782" class="cbody">
      <p>but especially with more recent bands (which, i think, you listen to less?), i’m seeing exactly the opposite effect- because of how tracks/etc are released now, a lot of artists have a first album comprised of material from an independently released EP, a single they put out via their website, etc- and then their SECOND album is the first real well constructed album with new cool ideas.</p>
<p>i would certainly agree with you pre, say, 1995 though.</p>

<a name="92718535"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92718535">
  <div id="comment_inner_92718535" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92718535">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92718535'); return false">It's a little like politics, honestly. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92718535" class="cbody">
      <p>Rather than paying attention to the product, name recognition gives you the option of judging how you feel about it based on how you feel about the group it belongs to. Convenient.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92718535">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 11:16 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92718350'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92718535); return false" id="comment_reply_92718535">reply</a>

    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92804369" class="cbody">
      <p>Still, “alias” was a great show.</p>
<p>I don’t think she has terrific range but she’s very good in the roles that fit her. I saw her in “13 going on 30” (don’t ask why I watched it) which I wholly expected to be absolutely terrible, but she brought a very likable energy to a generally weak script. I thought she did a very good job in Juno of playing an annoyingly type A but ultimately sympathetic would-be mother.</p>

<a name="92716994"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92716994">
  <div id="comment_inner_92716994" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/581993/1989_bgh_Cropped_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92716994">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92716994'); return false">I guess I don't read his quotes as pouting.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92716994" class="cbody">
      <p>Do you? I read them as: “My agent is handling it. I’d like to get a deal done, if the money is right because I like playing in St. Louis. If the money isn’t right, thought, I’ll test free agency.”</p>
<p>I think having Strauss as the man covering this beat for the Post-Dispatch makes it rather intolerable. He tweets that it is a “line in the sand” from Molina, but then the quotes from Molina and his agent make it clear that they aren’t saying a deal must be done by Opening Day or it won’t be done.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"I'm gonna throw the nastiest curveball I have ever thrown...if he hits it, I'll tip my cap, but if not we're going to the Series."</p>

<p>--Adam Wainwright on the final pitch of the 2006 NLCS</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/bgh">bgh</a> on

<a name="92729547"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92729547">
  <div id="comment_inner_92729547" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">

<a name="92802407"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92802407">
  <div id="comment_inner_92802407" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s."><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/169449/images_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92802407">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92802407'); return false">I'm not sure why people have a problem with molina's comments at all.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92802407" class="cbody">
      <p>I’d much rather have a player be honest and say “it’s business” than say it’s not yet still take a more lucrative offer.</p>
<p>It is a business. Nobody has a problem with the fact that allen craig makes $450k, even though less deserving players make more. We openly discuss how to maximize the club’s return by making sure the team spends as little as possible for the best value (emphasize the value of pre-arb, club controlled players; limit the length of contracts to avoid paying old players past their prime).</p>
<p>Why shouldn’t we extend ballplayers the same respect? It is a business. If yadier molina said that he wants to play well and stay healthy so he makes more money, good for him. That’s how it’s supposed to work. Yadi naturally will want to make a lot of money. So does Bill Dewitt.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>i used to be disgusted, but now i try to be amused . . . - macmanus</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s.">tom s.</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92802407">
          
            Feb 23, 2012 12:49 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
       via mobile
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92729772'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92802407); return false" id="comment_reply_92802407">reply</a>

    <div id="comment_body_92721041" class="cbody">
      <p>Worst part of the article: “by Jeff Gordon.”</p>
<p>The good news is you get that statement right at the top and it spares you having to waste 10 minutes reading the whole poorly conceived argument that follows.  Such time management is important to a happy life.</p>
<p>Assuming the article says what I think it does, I’ll guarantee that the day after Yadi leaves us, Gordon will be the first guy out with an article explaining why it was a genius move by team management to let him go.</p>

<a name="92724104"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92724104">
  <div id="comment_inner_92724104" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/PugetSoundCardsAddict"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/539732/Old-St-Louis-Beer_1__small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92724104">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92724104'); return false">I've just read the article and while I find it doesn't break any fresh ground</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92724104" class="cbody">
      <p>it does a reasonable job of summarizing salient reasons for getting Yadi under contract. My take is that much of the future of this team is tied up in young pitching (Garcia, Miller, Jenkins, Rosenthal, Lynn, Rzep, etc) There is a dearth of good catchers in the sport right now. Talk about Yadi’s “twilight” years seems a bit premature to me – he’s coming into his age 29 season and a 4 year extension only would take him through 33. What better place to spend the Pujols dividend?</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Beer and Baseball. Baseball and Beer. It's not hard to reevaluate your priorities when you only have two.</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/PugetSoundCardsAddict">PugetSoundCardsAddict</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92724104">

      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92722419'); return false">I feel like the iPhone app is way too bulky</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92722419" class="cbody">
      <p>You have to go through several different pages before you actually get to the comments section, and once you’re there, the app starts lagging and it just barely works. I do think the z’ing feature in the comments is kind of nice, but it’s not worth the crap you have to go through. I used it twice before I went back to SBN mobile on Safari.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>By gosh!</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/hr">hr</a> on 
      <span class="time">

    <div id="comment_body_92726512" class="cbody">

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92726832">
  <div id="comment_inner_92726832" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92726832">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92726832'); return false">I can't speak to the latter, but the former has not been my experience in the least</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92726832" class="cbody">
      <p>designing a single mobile site that works across multiple browsers is much easier than making dedicated apps for (at least) Android, iOS, WP7. Plus, you don’t have to deal with Apple’s review process, or write a new app for every new platform (e.g., the android app isn’t in the amazon store for the Fire).</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92727809">
  <div id="comment_inner_92727809" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/151728/dollabill_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92727809">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92727809'); return false">I can't speak to that specific functionality</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92727809" class="cbody">
      <p>but take a look at some of Google’s mobile apps to get a sense of what’s possible (gmail and gchat in particular). Facebook’s new mobile app is also very full featured. The only things you really miss in my experience are notifications and (to a certain extent) offline support.</p>
<p>My brother and I have a web-app based startup, and we’ve never felt inhibited by having chosen to develop a mobile site instead of an app.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/brackenthebox">brackenthebox</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92727809">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 1:02 PM EST
          
        </a>

<a name="92724063"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92724063">
  <div id="comment_inner_92724063" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Tackle%20Box"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/15348/wildcat_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92724063">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92724063'); return false">I have the android app on my phone and never use it</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92724063" class="cbody">
      <p>I actually find the mobile site to work pretty good for what I’m looking for.  Get’s me straight to where I want to go, I don’t have to fish though some random stories that always grab my attention but I’m not really interested in, and besides, I don’t really comment much on my phone so its usually to see if theres new info.</p>
<p>Actually, since VEB is typically a one post a day blog with a million comments, I don’t find visiting with my phone to be too convenient at all.  I do find my other sbn sites that don’t have as many comments and post more often (like in a more breaking news style) to be quite easy to get info from via my phone.  VEB is more of a conversation and if I’m out of pocket, I don’t have time for the conversation anyway.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>This life's hard, man, but it's harder if you're stupid.</p>

<p>- Jackie Brown</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Tackle%20Box">Tackle Box</a> on

  <div id="comment_inner_92717522" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92717522">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92717522'); return false">I could see Bo Hart managing a Denny's. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92717522" class="cbody">
      <p>I could also see Ray King managing to crack 400 lbs.</p>
<p>I’ve always thought Reggie Sanders would make a good manager somewhere down the road. Not necessarily on knowledge, because I don’t honestly know about that aspect of him, but he seems like the sort of personality who could coax a clubhouse through pretty much anything.</p>
<p>I could see Carpenter as a pitching coach. Doing the Leo Mazzone yell at the umpire nonstop thing.</p>
<p>Mark Grudzielanek always seemed to me like the sort who would go into coaching down the line.</p>
<p>I’m sure there are others, but I’m drawing a blank at the moment.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92717522">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 11:02 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92716920'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92717522); return false" id="comment_reply_92717522">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92717522" class="tools">

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92717769">

<a name="92718104"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92718104">
  <div id="comment_inner_92718104" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92718104">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92718104'); return false">Yikes. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92718104" class="cbody">
      <p>That’s a tough one. Especially since Hall of Fame Manager has such a nebulous actual meaning.</p>
<p>I will say this: Matheny is in a remarkably good spot, considering how highly the Cardinals value stability. There’s a good chance he’ll stick around for quite a while, which is really the biggest requirement to be a Hall of Fame manager anyway. Still, I can’t think the chances are any better than, say, 15%. And that’s probably being awfully optimistic.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>

      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92812802'); return false">Not that long ago</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92812802" class="cbody">
      <p>I was talking with someone else who writes/wrote regularly about baseball and we both agreed that 2011 was a difficult year. Being realistic about 2011 and writing about it were largely incompatible because of the outcomes.  As a result you were labelled a downer.</p>
<p>Last year was just weird for me.  2004-2005 were incredible. Those will always be my favorite seasons. I liked the 2006 postseason better than the 2011 one.</p>

<a name="92723586"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723586">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723586" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723586">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723586'); return false">Wow. That is pretty brutal. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723586" class="cbody">
      <p>Montero or Iannetta would probably make decent options. Napoli will never make it to free agency. Hell, Montero might not either.</p>
<p>The dream, of course, would be to use a big chunk of the farm depth the Cards have build and try to swing a deal for a guy like Matt Wieters if the Orioles decide to go whole hog on the rebuild.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92723586">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 12:16 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92723326'); return false">up</a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92718901">
  <div id="comment_inner_92718901" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/mattyp"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/185187/robot_himself_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92718901">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92718901'); return false">OT: I feel like I am betraying everything I hold dear, but....I am going to ask a fashion</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92718901" class="cbody">
      <p>question, with the hopeful intention that it will not digress into a huge skinny tie subthread. Ok, here goes: I am a pants person. I don’t think I’ve bought a pair of shorts in 5 good years. But an impending vacation makes it necessary, so I was wondering whether plain khakis are the way to go, or is a (not too obnoxious) plaid pattern okay, or something else? I literally have no idea what kind of shorts people wear these days.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>my favorite words are goodbye and my favorite color is red</p></div>

      <p>that being said, i think “Zack” is a sophomoric and silly way to spell one’s name. Zac, i can live with, but unless your given name is actually “Zackary” (i have met only one person in my life for whom this is true), i think it’s dumb.</p>
<p>this is probably one of the reasons i don’t like Zack Cox as much as most people do</p>

<a name="92719172"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92719172">
  <div id="comment_inner_92719172" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92719172">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92719172'); return false">I really like madras. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92719172" class="cbody">
      <p>Be bold, and have some fun. You’re on vacation, and it’s summer. Take a chance. Buy something you aren’t entirely certain of and then wear the living hell out of those bitches.</p>
<p>That being said, khaki is just fine as well, so long as you’re willing to use is as a base for something interesting. Whatever you do, though, make sure you buy something that fits. Above the knee, if at all possible. Far too many men rock the ridiculous baggy overly long shorts look, and they just look terrible.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron">the red baron</a> on

      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92722982'); return false">It's possible. </a>

    <div id="comment_body_92722982" class="cbody">
      <p>Rogue’s flagship is Dead Guy Ale, which is fine, but nothing special.</p>
<p>The Stone varieties almost all have gargoyle motifs to the labeling.</p>
<p>Avery is easily confused with Stone, but produce better quality overall in my opinion. (Avery is also the king of ridiculous ABV beers. Try a Mephistopheles sometime.)</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div>

<a name="92744295"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92744295">
  <div id="comment_inner_92744295" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Robth"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/492415/Bear7_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92744295">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92744295'); return false">it's a good thing for a treat</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92744295" class="cbody">
      <p>I’ve grabbed a couple single bottle rogues in the past—I remember liking their stout pretty well—and I don’t mind it as long as I can just get one to try. None of them are great enough to make me want to spend on a six pack.</p>
<p>Stone, on the other hand, I will put down the money for, at least when I want a beer to smack me in the mouth with a lot of hops on a hot summer day.  I find them to be among the best-balanced really hoppy beers.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Robth">Robth</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92744295">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 4:15 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92730885">
  <div id="comment_inner_92730885" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/azruavatar"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/526295/BenderMad_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>

      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92730885'); return false">That sounds about right.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92730885" class="cbody">
      <p>I generally find that all IPAs are like a punch in the mouth and I have no beer palate left after one. I always try to end on an IPA if I’m out tasting.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Beware: Velociraptors may be present.</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">

<a name="92803466"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92803466">
  <div id="comment_inner_92803466" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s."><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/169449/images_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92803466">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92803466'); return false">maybe. but what the market will bear for a top-flight defensive catcher</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92803466" class="cbody">
      <p>Remains totally undefined. Right now, you offer him something respectable but conservative (4y/$40m). If he rejects it, he wants to test the market anyway, and you’ll really have to overpay to overwhelm that bent.</p>
<p>You offer him the 1y/$12.5m required to get compensation after the WS, and maybe the same offer bumped up a little more ($44m? $48m?) if 2012 was a good year. If he turns both down, you wait for him to get another offer, and then compete.</p>
<p>It doesn’t make sense to get into uncharted waters for catcher compensation by bidding against yourself.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>i used to be disgusted, but now i try to be amused . . . - macmanus</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s.">tom s.</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92803466">
          
            Feb 23, 2012 1:06 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
       via mobile
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92719149'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92803466); return false" id="comment_reply_92803466">reply</a>

<a name="92721772"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92721772">
  <div id="comment_inner_92721772" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Cardinals645"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/235473/Cards80s_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92721772">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92721772'); return false">This year's draft should be very interesting for a number of reasons. What should we be expecting?</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92721772" class="cbody">
      <p>From a narrative view, there’s the idea of the comp. picks to “replace” Albert, there’s the large number of picks in general following a massive FA departure, and from a VEB-FR perspective there’s Kantrovitz replacing Luhnow, the new draft rules, etc. Do you think the Cards will look to exploit a player falling down boards, or mostly play it safe in terms of cash? Do they come close to using the $9+ million in the allowed pool? It’s probably even harder to guess how the picks will look in terms of upside vs floor, and positions, but if you’ve an opinion on those I’d be interested to hear them.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Chief Economist of Tyler Greene Fanclub </p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Cardinals645">Cardinals645</a> on 
      <span class="time">

<a name="92722588"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92722588">
  <div id="comment_inner_92722588" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92722588">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92722588'); return false">There's really too much uncertainty at this point with a new drafting guy to call it. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92722588" class="cbody">
      <p>But, I think the large number of picks, combined with the remarkable state of the farm system, will lead the organisation to take at least a few risks in those first sixish selections.</p>
<p>I would project a balance of risks and a few predictable college arms. And I’m okay with that. I do think they prioritise catcher if it’s available, and possibly lean toward adding a power bat or two.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723029">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723029" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Cardinals645"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/235473/Cards80s_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723029">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723029'); return false">Yea, I think there will be some sort of mix. With that many picks, I just can't imagine them not getting one or two high upside players,</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723029" class="cbody">
      <p>And I have too much respect for them to think they’ll go 100% “Moneyball”.</p>
<p>What do you think of the dearth of RHBs in the system in general? (The only RHB of consequence I can think of is Tommy Pham.) Mere coincidence, or the result (direct or indirect) of some sort of strategy? VEB tends to lean very much toward “best player available”, but should they consider looking for a RHB over a lefth-handed one?</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Chief Economist of Tyler Greene Fanclub </p></div>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92723417">
  <div id="comment_inner_92723417" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/the%20red%20baron"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/248016/trigun_001_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92723417">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92723417'); return false">I don't know I would lean toward a player only because of handedness. </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92723417" class="cbody">
      <p>There might be some benefit in it, but I honestly don’t know.</p>
<p>As far as the lack of right-handed hitters, I think it’s mostly just a coincidence. Same way with the utter absence of left-handed pitching. I don’t think there’s anything systemic about either; I think things have just worked out that way for now.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Who'd want to be a man of the people when there's people like you? </p></div>

    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92739593">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92739593'); return false">1994, Eastern Conference Finals </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92739593" class="cbody">
      <p>NY Rangers down two games to three against the hated Devils. Game 6 is in the swamp. Mark Messier, Ranger captain, guarantees a win in game 6 to bring it home to the Garden. He assists on a Kovalev goal, but going into the 3rd period, he rattles off a natural hat trick on his way to becoming the first man to captain two separate teams to a Stanley Cup.</p>
      
    </div>

<a name="92737115"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92737115">
  <div id="comment_inner_92737115" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92737115">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92737115'); return false">Don't teams in that situation run ISOs a lot because they don't have a full 24 second clock</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92737115" class="cbody">
      <p>and aren’t in the best position to run their complete offense in 8-16 seconds (or whatever is the average time left in these situations)?</p>
<p>The other reason of course is that it gives the team’s best player a chance to score or get fouled.  If you’ve got one possession, you give it to your best player (especially if there are “time” issues and you can’t run your regular offense).  But that doesn’t mean you’d give your best player 75 ISO possessions in a row.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92737115">

<a name="92737652"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92737652">
  <div id="comment_inner_92737652" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/495138/DrunkDog_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92737652">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92737652'); return false">because if you do that, they will start double/triple/etc teaming that player until he gives the ball up- this is just how basketball is played</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92737652" class="cbody">
      <p>also, it burns the player out, and stagnates your offense.</p>
<p>the best offenses in basketball i have seen are those in which all 5 players on the court are a legitimate offensive threat, but also with an exceptional scorer or two- it makes the defense respect every player on the court, opens things up, and creates movement. and in basketball, movement is what leads to easy baskets. all it takes is for one defender to slip/react incorrectly, and you have an open basket.</p>
<p>an isolation play, on the other hand, stops everything, and makes it all about one player beating one player- if he doesn’t, there’s not going to be a basket off the isolation. it kills the flow of the game.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>mumble mumble Peter Bourjos mumble mumble</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak">tehzachatak</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92737652">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 2:57 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92737962">
  <div id="comment_inner_92737962" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/mysterui"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/439861/yRDWns_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92737962">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92737962'); return false">I've never understood an ISO to be "you take the shot, fuck everything else"</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92737962" class="cbody">
      <p>You make a move, if you drive to the basket and someone doubles you, then kick it out.  You’d get a lot of open looks for 3, would you not?</p>
<p>I don’t know that a bunch of ISOs burns a player anymore than running through an offense. That seems like an assertion without evidence</p>
<p>“best offenses” thing is anecdotal</p>

<a name="92738693"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92738693">
  <div id="comment_inner_92738693" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/495138/DrunkDog_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92738693">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92738693'); return false">no, you're not</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92738693" class="cbody">
      <p>my opinion here is colored by watching a vast amount of NBA in the past 5 years, and a BIT of college basketball. that’s what i watch. for better or for worse, what i usually see is someone like Melo isoing up, and i don’t see very many open 3s coming off that.</p>
<p>think about Lin, for example. he gets people open all the time when he drives to the basket, but those aren’t isolation plays. those are plays that often involve screens, and come in the flow of the offense. someone comes over to double, and bam, he dumps it off- but he usually has a guy right open.</p>
<p>if you’re running a true clearout iso, especially in these end of game scenarios you’re talking about, where defenders are going to be especially conscious of their man, you have to be a pretty damn good passer to hit the open guy if someone doubles down, and USUALLY, the guy who doubles down will be someone guarding the man on the floor who is NOT a 3pt threat.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>mumble mumble Peter Bourjos mumble mumble</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak">tehzachatak</a> on

<a name="92738462"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92738462">
  <div id="comment_inner_92738462" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/76654/Willie_McGee_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92738462">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92738462'); return false">Your assertion that teams always run ISOs at the end of games is anecdotal.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92738462" class="cbody">
      <p>Is it because Kobe takes a lot of shots at the end of close games?</p>
<p>Also, it’s intutively logically (if not completely obvious) that funneling the entire offense through one player for the entire game to make one-on-one moves and shots, game after game, is going to tax that player more.</p>
<p>Running more and jumping more = more wear-and-tear, fouls received,  and more fatigue.  If you think running more and jumping more, and getting hacked more doesn’t make a player more tired, <em>you</em> come up with the evidence to dispute that.</p>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/Willie%20McGee's%20Twin">Willie McGee's Twin</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92738462">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 3:06 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92737962'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92738462); return false" id="comment_reply_92738462">reply</a>

<a name="92738950"></a>

    </h5>
