<a name="92737432"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92737432">
  <div id="comment_inner_92737432" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/495138/DrunkDog_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92737432">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92737432'); return false">well-</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92737432" class="cbody">
      <p>i’m not sure when a team needs to score, all teams will use an isolation play. a team like the Denver Nuggets of 2-3 years ago, with a transcendent scorer (Carmelo Anthony) who excels in isolation situations, and a team of scrubs behind him, sure. but in those situations, a lot of professional teams that do not have this specific set of personnel will run something like a pick and roll, attempting to EITHER get an easy basket (unlikely) or forcing a defensive switch to a favorable matchup where an isolation play is exceptionally successful.</p>
<p>here’s why i think this happens, though- for better or for worse, NBA teams: a. would like their best player/closer to take the final shot, so that they can say they “gave it their best effort”, and b. do not want their final possession to end in a turnover.</p>
<p>what’s the most likely play to get your best player a decent shot? an isolation play. does this mean that this is the highest points per play option in the playbook? probably not- but maybe, for example, a pick and roll play that is your “best” play also yields a fairly high number of turnovers that, in a vacuum, are balanced out by the higher chance of you scoring on the play- but in a final shot scenario, will end the game without you even getting a shot up.</p>
<p>finally- i think the fatigue factor is a big deal. you’re hoping, with these plays, to get your best player matched up one on one with his defender- and if he’s really your best player, he should have ground this guy down all game.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>mumble mumble Peter Bourjos mumble mumble</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak">tehzachatak</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92737432">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 2:54 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92736428'); return false">up</a>
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92737432); return false" id="comment_reply_92737432">reply</a>
      <span class="cactions">  
        <span id="comment_tools_92737432" class="tools">
          <a href="#" class="actions_link" onclick="SBN.Comments.loadTools(92737432); return false">actions</a>
        </span>
        <span id="comment_rating_92737432">&nbsp; 
          
        </span>
      </span>
    </p>
  </div>
  <div id="comment_form_container_92737432"></div>

<a name="92738339"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92738339">
  <div id="comment_inner_92738339" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/495138/DrunkDog_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92738339">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92738339'); return false">probably, yeah- i would say there is no more reason to run an iso at the end of a game than there is any other particular play</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92738339" class="cbody">
      <p>i still think it is proper to run a vast variety of plays, to keep the defense off balance, all your players involved, get different looks/matchups, etc.</p>
<p>just because you have an absolutely deadeye 3pt shooter does not mean you are going to run a disproportionately large number of plays to get him 3s, are you? just like an incredible post offense player isn’t going to have all the plays run through him. more than the average team, sure, but there is a real role for offensive variety in basketball.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>mumble mumble Peter Bourjos mumble mumble</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tehzachatak">tehzachatak</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92738339">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 3:04 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<a name="92740219"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92740219">
  <div id="comment_inner_92740219" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/hittmeier"><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/460431/7832_553217475816_23508752_32716564_3360297_n_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92740219">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92740219'); return false">I posted this upthread but</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92740219" class="cbody">
      <p>I really do believe a big part of the ISO being the last shot play has to do with when the shot has to take place.  It is hard to predict when a shot will happen when it occurs naturally through the offense and teams really hate leaving time on the clock.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>"We will see you....Tomorrow Night"</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/hittmeier">hittmeier</a> on 
      <span class="time">

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92740408">
  <div id="comment_inner_92740408" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/joker24"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/4819/Mizzou_logo_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92740408">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92740408'); return false">And for good reason</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92740408" class="cbody">
      <p>Even if you leave enough time for the opposing team to score only 30% of the time, you’re better off wasting the extra amount of time and making your own opportunity go from say 50% to 40%</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Not afraid to nitpick</p></div>

<a name="92746034"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92746034">
  <div id="comment_inner_92746034" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/all4tookie"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/120970/3341_633586789887_5605975_37208363_4035095_n_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92746034">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92746034'); return false">anecdote alert - </a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92746034" class="cbody">
      <p>Sebastian Pruiti breaks down OKC’s typical reliance on isolation at the end of games and how/why they had been unsuccessful.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.grantland.com/blog/the-triangle/post/_/id/16872/oklahoma-city-uses-screen-the-screener-concept-gets-durant-an-open-look" target="_blank">http://www.grantland.com/blog/the-triangle/post/_/id/16872/oklahoma-city-uses-screen-the-screener-concept-gets-durant-an-open-look</a></p>
<p>One idea is that end of games are fundamentally different situations because refs tend to swallow the whistle.  I have no proof of this, but it is certainly possible.</p>
<blockquote>Durant’s lack of strength has hindered him late in games. Too often, stronger defenders knock him off his path, and screens and cuts become ineffective. For this reason, the Thunder tend to isolate Durant to make sure that he gets the ball.</blockquote>
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/all4tookie">all4tookie</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92746034">
          
            Feb 22, 2012 4:37 PM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
        <a class="up_link" href="#" title="jump up to parent" onclick="SBN.Comments.scrollTo('comment_item_92736428'); return false">up</a>

<a name="92800482"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92800482">
  <div id="comment_inner_92800482" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Ghost%20of%20Todd%20Burns"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/564072/carlosicon_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92800482">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92800482'); return false">I'm not judging Westbrook on last year.</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92800482" class="cbody">
      <p>I’m judging him and Oswalt on their entire careers.  Westbrook’s contract or NTC shouldn’t matter when picking your 5 best starters. Oswalt shouldn’t have to prove he’s better than Westy because he’s proved it for the last 11 seasons. Saying Garland or Harang don’t have the same contract as Westy is pointless because I’m suggesting that if the cards signed a pitcher like that instead of Oswalt…then it could be reasonable to have them battle for a 5th rotation spot because they’ve had similar careers.  There is nothing similar about the careers of Westy and Oswalt.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Trade Westbrook</p></div>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92802616">
  <div id="comment_inner_92802616" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Ghost%20of%20Todd%20Burns"><img src="http://cdn2.sbnation.com/profile_images/564072/carlosicon_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92802616">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92802616'); return false">I think the Cardinals just need to be more bold about this..</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92802616" class="cbody">
      <p>I think they are afraid Westy won’t waive the NTC.  However, if they just go ahead and bring Oswalt in, Westy will obviously be more open to it knowing he isn’t guaranteed a spot in the rotation.  Sure, it’s risky, but I don’t see this being a terrible PR move for future players nor do I think Westy would just decide that he is okay pitching out of the pen. Westy ain’t waiving the NTC because he has no reason to right now.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Trade Westbrook</p></div>

      <p>and we still do not know how many teams will make the playoffs this year.  Bizarre.</p>

<a name="92803166"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92803166">
  <div id="comment_inner_92803166" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Continental"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/599628/TheContenental_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92803166">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92803166'); return false">Random:</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92803166" class="cbody">
      <blockquote><a href="http://thisgameofgames.blogspot.com/2012/02/st-louis-cricket-club.html" target="new">I’ve always argued that the tradition of various bat and ball games in St. Louis</a> provided an infrastructure that the New York game used to help establish itself.  There were clubs, grounds and a tradition of playing bat and ball games among adults in St. Louis prior to the advent of the New York game in the city in 1859.  The new game latched onto these traditions and the community of ballplayers gravitated to the new game.  The traditions that surrounded the playing of town ball and cricket in St. Louis made it easier for the new game to be accepted and grow in St. Louis.  I think that the fact that some of the original Empire Club members were cricketers supports that argument.</blockquote>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Retire #52!</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Continental">The Continental</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92803166">
          
            Feb 23, 2012 1:00 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
      
      
      <a href="#" class="reply_link" title="reply to this comment" onclick="SBN.Comments.reply(2580450,92803166); return false" id="comment_reply_92803166">reply</a>

<a name="92805527"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92805527">
  <div id="comment_inner_92805527" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Continental"><img src="http://cdn3.sbnation.com/profile_images/599628/TheContenental_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92805527">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92805527'); return false">Not sure of the actual mechanics of what he calls "town ball"</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92805527" class="cbody">
      <p>Thought this was interesting:</p>
<blockquote>As I’ve mentioned before, Lincoln, when he moved to Illinois, arrived in a community that had a vibrant ballplaying culture. <a href="http://thisgameofgames.blogspot.com/2010/07/lincoln-baseball-legend-great-ball.html" target="new">A baseball variant, that the locals specifically remembered as being called town ball, was played in central Illinois in the 1820s and 1830s.</a> Other ball games that were played during the antebellum era included bullpen, cross out and long town. I mentioned in a previous post that Lincoln had a reputation as a being a good fives player. Ball playing was a large part of the culture of central Illinois and it would have been atypical of Lincoln not to take part in these games. </blockquote>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>Retire #52!</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/The%20Continental">The Continental</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92805527">
          
            Feb 23, 2012 1:58 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>

<p>i haven’t locked down specific figures, but i’ve been at my job 2 months and am about to get a raise in the vicinity of 70% considering guaranteed bonuses. i’ll be making as much as or maybe more than my dad at his primary job. i was a little nervous about sending an email asking for a 100% raise, but it could the most profitable email i will ever send assuming that future salaries and raises are loosely based on previous salaries</p>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92803699">
  <div id="comment_inner_92803699" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/FlimtotheFlam"><img src="http://cdn1.sbnation.com/profile_images/586592/avatar_small.png" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92803699">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92803699'); return false">Just don't take it for granted</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92803699" class="cbody">
      <p>With a new raise. I would start looking at your finances very seriously. I would pay off any remaining debts and start shifting additional revenue into investment. I used to make a little under 6 figures for 2 years than it all fell apart. Lucky for me I didn’t waste all that money I made.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p><a href="http://vebproxy.appspot.com/" target="new">VEB Proxy</a></p></div>

<a name="92807097"></a>

<div class="citem" id="comment_item_92807097">
  <div id="comment_inner_92807097" class="comment cpic not-new clearfix">
    
        <a class="pic" href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s."><img src="http://cdn0.sbnation.com/profile_images/169449/images_small.jpg" width="32" height="32"></a>
    
    <h5 class="comment_title" id="comment_title_92807097">
      <a href="#" onclick="SBN.Comments.toggleComment('comment_body_92807097'); return false">lynn and swagerty missed a chance to throw earlier</a>
    </h5>
    <div id="comment_body_92807097" class="cbody">
      <p>This week. Lynn had a leg, which sounded like nothing more than cramping or stiffness; even if it’s a hamstring pull or something, he’d recover fairly quickly and surgery-free.</p>
<p>The report on swagerty was more concerning. Initially they just said he had an arm. Then there was a very quiet “elbow inflammation with bone spurs” comment. That makes me incredibly nervous. I suppose it could be nothing more than mild inflammation that gets some rest, ice and a cortisone shot (or coors and a shot), but these kind of injuries seem like they lead to minor surgery to remove the spurs in good cases and TJ in the bad cases.</p>
<p>Scoot, other VEBers who know more about ortho than me, console me/tell me I’m right.</p>
      
        <div class="sig"><p>i used to be disgusted, but now i try to be amused . . . - macmanus</p></div> 
      
    </div>
    <p class="by">
      by <a href="http://www.sbnation.com/users/tom%20s.">tom s.</a> on 
      <span class="time">
        <a class="tz-convert" href="#92807097">
          
            Feb 23, 2012 3:37 AM EST
          
        </a>
      </span>
       via mobile
